data.profileText: a Representative from Ohio; born in Mercersburg, Franklin County, Pa., October 12, 1770; attended the public schools; moved to Cincinnati, Ohio, in 1793; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced; member of the Ohio territorial legislative council in 1798; United States receiver of public moneys at Cincinnati in 1800; United States marshal of Ohio in 1802; member of the Ohio state house of representatives in 1803; mayor of Cincinnati in 1805 and 1806, and again in 1810 and 1811; served in the War of 1812 as colonel of the Second Ohio Volunteer Infantry; elected as a Jacksonian candidate to the Nineteenth and to the three succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1825-March 3, 1833); was not a candidate for renomination in 1832; unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Governor of Ohio in 1834; died in Cincinnati, Ohio, December 28, 1835; interment in Spring Grove Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1823, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Findlay to Isaac D. Bernard written on October 15, 1823. In the letter, Findlay reports Democratic majorities in Pennsylvania local elections.

researchRecord.name: In Aaron Torrence Collection, 1790-1856. 21 feet (2,171 items).
researchRecord.description: Unpublished calendar in repository. Also described in published guide (1887).

researchRecord.name: 1 letter (1828), written from Washington, in the Moses Dawson correspondence, 1811-1845. 178 letters.
researchRecord.description: Inventory list available. Also on microfilm.
